item.title: andrewducker | A modest proposal on avoiding massive international computer failures
item.description: I propose that if you supply software to more than X customers (say 10,000 but I'm totally open to discussion on this point) then you must have insurance that covers you for legal liability for damages.
item.author: (timeasmymeasure)

item.title: Interface design in the age of qualiatech: Do you want to be a button?
item.description: There have been many times in my life that I have felt at one with a computer screen, but one in particular stands out – when I discovered something called Max/MSP during one of my second-year classes at university. Max/MSP is a visual programming language, where instead of writing a program by typing text into a text editor, the programmer manipulates a directed acyclic graph of nodes on a canvas. Generally this is used for novel realtime audio/video production.

item.title: An interactive guide to x86-64 assembly - moving data
item.description: This is the second part of a series of interactive articles on the x86-64 architecture. This part will focus on the first assembly instructions, visualizing the way data moves in memory when they are executed.

item.title: Carving ELF Files
item.description: Recently, I created a simple tool, Carve Exe, to carve executables from other files (e.g. memory dumps or network traffic). Carving executables from binary blobs is a common task in digital forensics and reverse engineering. For example, when analyzing how a malware sample unpacks and deobfuscates itself.

item.title: Modchipping a fridge
item.description: I own a fridge that has a really cool ‘feature’. It beeps if the door is open for more than 60 seconds. 95% of the time this is more annoying than it is helpful. In my opinion it should just shut up and trust that I know best.

item.title: Scan HTML even faster with SIMD instructions (C++ and C#) – Daniel Lemire's blog
item.description: Earlier this year, both major Web engines (WebKit/Safari and Chromium/Chrome/Edge/Brave) accelerated HTML parsing using SIMD instructions. These ‘SIMD’ instructions are special instructions that are present in all our processors that can process multiple bytes at once (e.g., 16 bytes).

item.description: With the recent developments in US politics, following the attempt on candidate Donald Trump's life there is renewed heated and polarised debate, if there wasn't such heat before. With this, something struck me as odd when talking to other people online, which is, nothing seems to be changing.

item.title: Why disallow package within the class name?
item.description: Motivation After opening a directory it is the developers job to filter out the files that are not relevant to their task at hand. The more words to filter, the more difficult it becomes to quickly orient themselves and start making changes. Disallowing package within the class name promises to reduce this information overload.
item.author: (Garrett D Bates)

item.title: Buy or Rent? RaspberryPi vs VPS

item.title: Why prefer unit testing through layer entrypoints?
item.description: Status Quo There is significant artistic variance on how to craft tests which provide developers quick and useful feedback. A common point of contention is the number of files which should be included within these quick and useful tests. The most popular strategy is to have a single file under test at a time.
